content.description: Short route with some fun moves. Cool holds on the top half.
content.location: 50 yards south from Late Night Chalk Show on the same level.

content.protection: Trad or scramble to the top to set TR.
content.location: Crack just right of "Who is Bernd Arnold?"

climbs.name: Riverboat Hustler
climbs.fa: Aaron “The Batman” Geistfeld, Garrett Hopkins, and Clif Sathoff

content.description: Harder than Riverboat gambler, more overhang time, harder slab, a bolt that can easily be clipped at the overhang so you don’t deck and feel easier on the climb…….. this route has all that. Note this isn’t saying Gambler is a bad route, it’s an amazing route and hopefully this route is able to provide the same level of enjoyment and rating.
content.protection: 7 glue ins and anchor with rap rings at the top.  There’s a bolt drilled in for the belayer to lock into if there’s concerns of falling off the ledge
content.location: To the left of Riverboat gambler

content.description:
Slab to a cool roof pull.

 I TR'd the route but busted slightly right (See pics) before the last slab bolt and pulled on good fairly solid jugs over.
content.protection: 7 bolts. Option for an 8th bolt under the roof but most people skip it. Two bolt anchor with quicklinks.
content.location: To the right of "Pretty Piece of Flesh" is an impressive roof.

climbs.name: Riverboat Amateur
climbs.fa: Aaron “the Batman” Geistfeld and Garrett Hopkins

content.description: Necedah needed another good sport 5.8 and hopefully the amateur is the answer.  It’s not as exposed nor has the view as glass balls but it’s not a slab climb either.  Good hands, good feet and you get some nice intro moves ranging from stemming to sidepull that help you commit your way to the top.  Get warmed up on amateur then take on the gambler and if you feel lucky, finish on the hustler.
content.protection: 7 bolts and anchors at the top with rap rings.
content.location: To the right of Riverboat Gambler and the last route before you hit the crack scramble which gets you to the top of everything.

content.description:
Scramble up some ledges and pull onto the slab. The rock quality is impressive for the slab, and the moves are fun. Move up the increasingly steep rock to the joint of the overhanging arrette/fin. Clip the last two bolts in the overhang, and bust through a burly boulder problem, following the line straight up from the last bolt. Safest to stay off of the fin 6 feet to your left - the rock seems a little more rotten there (although it would probably make for easier climbing, but the obvious line is harder, more fun, and on good rock). 

  Once you've reached the top, traverse right to the anchor. Let out a good yell to show the locals how strong you are. 

  If you're lacking the cannonballs to lead, the TR isn't a good idea. If you blow it above the last bolt (at the crux) you're going to smack into the dihedral on your right. Probably a better idea to just enjoy punting into space on overhanging glue-ins.
content.protection: 7 bots to lower off. Glue ins!
content.location: The top cliff band that houses the rest of Above Anthrax has an obvious break about 100' to the South of "Who is Bernd Arnold? (5.8)". This is just left (South) of the impressive roof. The break in the cliff is punctuated by a huge fin sticking out of a green dihedral on the top right wall - that's your climb! Scramble through slippery pine needles to the bottom of the slab. It's easiest to belay from the trail, not the ledges.

content.description: This is the left-hand route on the block that follows three bolts to rusty chains. The climb is quite dirty (usually), but a fun (and potentially exhilarating...) fight up a sloping arrette.
content.location: This is 15 feet to the left of Late Night Chalk Show. Either lower off of the chains or untie and walk down the back side.

content.description: Scramble up the boulders to the right of the main block and pre-clip the first bolt from there. This route is short and very intense - significantly harder than Whiskey a go go (ultra classic...), but shorter. Grading is difficult due to the length, yet the crux (moving from the second to third bolt) is both sequence specific and powerful. Flex your huge muscles really hard and follow the arrette to chains. Then go have a beer.
content.location: This route is the right hand side of the block that follows the obvious angled arrette. On the right side of the upper arrette is an aesthetic finger crack. Lower off of the chains or untie and walk off the back side.

content.description: Want a better way to get the view?  This route offers better rock quality, and much better protection than Climb with a View.  Head to the road side of the tower that's host to Climb with a View.  Look for the vertical crack and head up.  The crux is low, but well protected.  Enjoy the chicken head holds at the top, and the amazing view.
content.location: North-west (road side) of the tower home to Climb with a View

content.description: A short gear lead using the face and a thin crack system in an obtuse dihedral.
content.protection: Small gear for the climb, med+ for the anchor
content.location: Left of Late Night and Ponyboy.

content.description:
Short, widening crack that ends at a flat ledge (crux)

 Can be climbed on gear at about 5.7. If a rope is used you can walk back to a large tree to bring up a second and rap. I used a yellow torquenut as a chockstone to keep the rope out of the depths of the crack.
content.location: Just left of Climb with a View

content.description: This block sits far on the North end of the bluff at the very top of the ridge. There are random, scattered climbs along this section of the bluff. Of note, however, is an East facing (towards the river) block with a broken corner arrette on the right hand side.
